Posts.Title: Looks like dad's headed to salvage radiation. Your experiences appreciated!

Posts.Content: I must echo the comments of the others here. Your situation, and mine, is what it is. Worry will not change a thing. I realized that a while back. If it would then I would worry my head off but it will do no good. I used to be in control of my life, or at least I thought I was. No more. Now I do the best I can to follow the Dr's advice, seek information and treatment options and the rest is out of my hands. It will be what it will be. Nick
Posts.Title: RO Meeting

Posts.Content: At 2 weeks I was a mess. By 9 weeks I was dry. Give it time.
Posts.Title: Incontinence questions

Posts.Content: At 2 weeks I was a mess. By 9 weeks I was dry. Give it time.
Posts.Title: Incontinence questions

Posts.Content: Prostate removed 9/16 but PSA was 0.6 afterwards rising to 1.0 over the next year. Had salvage radiation in late '17 with Lupron injections every 3 months(had the third about a month ago). Just had my PSA done and it's too low to measure. Doctor wants me to stay on Lupron for another year, then we'll ween me and see what happens. I know Lupron can drive PSA numbers down but can Lupron alone make the PSA too low to measure?
Posts.Title: Salvage radiation treatment followup

Posts.Content: Hi MM No specific numbers, so apparently that means undetectable. The test was ordered by my local care giver, not my RO. The results were: Total PSA <0.1 Free PSA <0.02 This was the first test in about a year. Doing well. Hope to stay that way. Hope you can say the same.
Posts.Title: Salvage radiation treatment followup

Posts.Content: RobLee My PSA post op plus 3 months was 0.6. My latest PSA test that I referred to was done as part of my annual physical at my local clinic. They apparently didn't do the more accurate test my RO does. So "undetectable" was my term, not their's for <0.1 total and <0.02 free PSA. Now my question, if Lupron by itself is able to drive the PSA to at or near zero, does that mean the Cancer, if any remaining after my RT, is inactive or just it's ability to produce measurable PSA numbers? In other words, in the presence of Lupron, is PSA still a good proxy for Cancer cell activity?
Posts.Title: Salvage radiation treatment followup

Posts.Content: Fairwind My Gleason score was 8 at biopsy downgraded to 7 at post op pathology.

Posts.Title: Salvage radiation treatment followup

Posts.Content: fly888 Do you really want to tempt fate?
Posts.Title: Testosterone after Prostate cancer

Posts.Content: MM My RO is doing uPSA and T testing. I just don't know what the results are. I mean it is what it is so do I need to follow it closely? It should be essentially zero so will a decimal point or two make any difference? Would I change the way I live when the outcome will be the same either way? No. Life itself is fatal, it's only a question of when. I prefer to enjoy the present and not worry too much about things I can't change.

Posts.Title: Woohoo!

Posts.Title: Woohoo!

Posts.Content: A PSA of 38 in mid 2016 followed by Da Vinci Surgery in Sept 2016. Still measurable PSA afterwards which led me to salvage radiation in the fall of 2017 along with starting hormonal treatment. Had my 7th lupron injection yesterday. I still can't believe how painless they are. One more to go in April. My PSA has been undetectable for over a year and a half and my Oncologist tells me I have a 50-60% chance of having been cured. If not then it is still very unlikely it will ever kill me. My experience on Lupron has been fatigue, lack of energy, loss of most body hair, zero libido, loss of muscle tone etc etc. Not too big a price to pay and I am assured the effects will reverse once the treatments ends. My care has been managed by the Banner Cancer Health Care Center which is an offshoot of the University of Arizona Medical Center in Tucson. My Oncologist is an MD, PHD and the Director of the Radiation Oncology Department. I feel truly blessed for the care I have received. My hope is that others here will fare as well as I have.
Posts.Title: 18 Months on Lupron update

Posts.Content: Hi MM and Rob. Yes, we've corresponded in the past. I don't have my detailed info. I'm 70 now and was diagnosed in 2016 with a gleason score of 8, downgraded to 7 post surgery. T is now <12. While a 50-60% chance of a cure isn't 100%, it's certainly better than the 0% chance I had post surgery, and the low chance of it ever killing me is probably more important than anything else. What I'm curious about is why they gave me these encouraging statistics now and not 6 months or so ago? Perhaps it was necessary to confirm the unmeasurable PSA and be sure I could tolerate Lupron. Wish I had remembered to ask but I was a bit discombobulated by encouraging news and their general upbeat tone. I felt like I was no longer just a victim but closer to a survivor. Sure looking forward to getting off this Lupron but with one more shot in April I guess it will be still quite a while before the boys get back to work producing T. Wishing all the best. Nick

Posts.Title: 18 Months on Lupron update

Posts.Title: 18 Months on Lupron update

Posts.Content: MM My surgery in 9/16 left me with measurable PSA so we decided to go the radiation route in 9-10/17 with the hope of affecting a cure. Lupron was started in 7/17 just prior to RT. So my current unmeasurable PSA is expected with the Lupron but it may also be the result of the RT doing it's job and knocking out the cancer. I asked this very question, how do we know if the RT worked as hoped when both a successful RT and Lupron will both result in the same unmeasurable PSA? The answer was "we won't know until you stop the Lupron". So no cure can be inferred hence the 50-60% likelihood. So why didn't they tell me this before? Upon reflection, I suspect there are new results from ongoing research and that's what they're quoting. Those results weren't available before. Additionally, a low probability of dying from PC in the next 10 years is not that different from a cure. Either way, I feel quite a bit better about my chances than I did a few days ago. Time, our most valuable commodity. Every year there are more treatments and more chances for a cure, but you have to be alive to benefit... Nick

Posts.Content: Otago The Surgeon may have been saying that I was an adult and he couldn't arrest me and get a court order. I was free to be stupid if I wanted. He strongly suggested surgery and I agreed.
Posts.Title: 10-Year Outcomes after Monitoring, Surgery, or Radiotherapy for Localized PCa

Posts.Content: Yours sounds almost exactly like mine, which was 18 days ago. I feel much better now. You will too. Good luck to you. Nick
Posts.Title: RRP Surgery done yesterday

Posts.Content: How remarkable that the survival rates for untreated aren't that much lower at 10 years compared to the other options. At 68 with my PSA of 38 and my Gleason score of 8 I thought the Surgeon was crazy when he offered me the option of just monitoring it. I chose removal and I'm glad I did and I don't think I'd do it any differently had I read this study before making my decision, but still it does give one pause... Nick
Posts.Title: 10-Year Outcomes after Monitoring, Surgery, or Radiotherapy for Localized PCa

Posts.Content: Fairwinf Thank you for adding your perspective. You are of course correct. My post op lab put me at G-7, down graded from my biopsy of G-8. Hard to say what would have happened to me had I done nothing but with the initial G-8 I wasn't going to chance it. Glad I chose to have it removed. 3 weeks post op today and feeling good. Just hoping for some bladder control... Nick
Posts.Title: 10-Year Outcomes after Monitoring, Surgery, or Radiotherapy for Localized PCa

Posts.Content: 17 days since robotic surgery. Radical prostatectomy with lymph node removal and seminal vertical removal as well at the University of Arizona at Tucson. Out of the hospital after 24 hours. No followup chemo or radiation required. My PSA was 38 and my Gleason score was 8 at biopsy and downgraded to 7 post op. 7 days since the catheter was taken out after 10 days (and not a moment too soon) and I wouldn't say I have any bladder control yet but I have some influence... Hoping for return of full control but I know it takes patience. Happy to be alive. Nick P.
Posts.Title: New Poster

Posts.Content: I know I posted above that I was able to take a standing pee, but that was after collecting while sitting down. I still have essentially zero control standing up, meaning it's straight thru from the kidneys while standing, no control over the matter. Is this normal after almost 3 weeks since surgery? Lying down and sitting is no problem. Nick.
Posts.Title: New Poster

Posts.Content: I don't have a copy of the lab report. I guess I'll get that when I have my followon visit on the 29th. There's a lesson here. At 68 because my health had been so good, I hadn't seen a doctor in years. I went into my local clinic because of a mole on my groin that concerned me. Turned out to be nothing but she suggested a physical because it had been so long. She freaked when she saw my PSA was 38 and rushed me off to a Urologist. The rest is now history but I'd be all but a dead man in a year or two if it weren't for that mole because I'd have never gone in for a blood test otherwise. For us aging men, and younger ones as well, all it takes is an almost painless blood test to catch something that is treatable and curable if caught early. My Physician told me, if you have to have cancer, this is the one to have. Right now I feel like the luckiest man in the world because I just stumbled on this in time by pure dumb luck, nothing more. Nick P.

Posts.Title: New Poster

Posts.Content: Thank you Toloh Had my first standing pee today. Meaning I was able to walk around and retain enough without leaking to actually take a pee intentionally! I guess that's pretty good for only 8 days off the catheter. Nick
Posts.Title: New Poster

Posts.Content: Thank you Toloh Had my first standing pee today. Meaning I was able to walk around and retain enough without leaking to actually take a pee intentionally! I guess that's pretty good for only 8 days off the catheter. Nick
Posts.Title: New Poster

Posts.Content: I don't have a copy of the lab report. I guess I'll get that when I have my followon visit on the 29th. There's a lesson here. At 68 because my health had been so good, I hadn't seen a doctor in years. I went into my local clinic because of a mole on my groin that concerned me. Turned out to be nothing but she suggested a physical because it had been so long. She freaked when she saw my PSA was 38 and rushed me off to a Urologist. The rest is now history but I'd be all but a dead man in a year or two if it weren't for that mole because I'd have never gone in for a blood test otherwise. For us aging men, and younger ones as well, all it takes is an almost painless blood test to catch something that is treatable and curable if caught early. My Physician told me, if you have to have cancer, this is the one to have. Right now I feel like the luckiest man in the world because I just stumbled on this in time by pure dumb luck, nothing more. Nick P.
Posts.Title: New Poster

Posts.Content: Thank you Toloh Had my first standing pee today. Meaning I was able to walk around and retain enough without leaking to actually take a pee intentionally! I guess that's pretty good for only 8 days off the catheter. Nick
Posts.Title: New Poster

Posts.Content: 17 days since robotic surgery. Radical prostatectomy with lymph node removal and seminal vertical removal as well at the University of Arizona at Tucson. Out of the hospital after 24 hours. No followup chemo or radiation required. My PSA was 38 and my Gleason score was 8 at biopsy and downgraded to 7 post op. 7 days since the catheter was taken out after 10 days (and not a moment too soon) and I wouldn't say I have any bladder control yet but I have some influence... Hoping for return of full control but I know it takes patience. Happy to be alive. Nick P.
Posts.Title: New Poster

Posts.Content: I know I posted above that I was able to take a standing pee, but that was after collecting while sitting down. I still have essentially zero control standing up, meaning it's straight thru from the kidneys while standing, no control over the matter. Is this normal after almost 3 weeks since surgery? Lying down and sitting is no problem. Nick.

Posts.Title: 6 Week Post-Op PSA results

Posts.Content: Thanks to all who replied. Nick
Posts.Title: Follow up Blood Test Too Soon?

Posts.Content: My prostate surgery was Oct 17th and my follow up appointment with my Urologist/Surgeon in Tucson is on November 29th. The Surgeon requested a PSA test one week before the appointment but for a variety or reasons, my long distance from Tucson requires I have the test done locally, Thanksgiving next week, etc, I had it done today. My concern is that after only 4 weeks since surgery, has my PSA (38 at surgery) had time to settle out by now? Will I show a misleadingly high score now due to the closeness to my surgery? Nick
Posts.Title: Follow up Blood Test Too Soon?

Posts.Content: My prostate surgery was Oct 17th and my follow up appointment with my Urologist/Surgeon in Tucson is on November 29th. The Surgeon requested a PSA test one week before the appointment but for a variety or reasons, my long distance from Tucson requires I have the test done locally, Thanksgiving next week, etc, I had it done today. My concern is that after only 4 weeks since surgery, has my PSA (38 at surgery) had time to settle out by now? Will I show a misleadingly high score now due to the closeness to my surgery? Nick
Posts.Title: Follow up Blood Test Too Soon?

Posts.Content: Michael - Re "my PSA (38 at surgery):" I'm guessing that this PSA of 38 earned you an appointment for your biopsy. If so, then your PSA at the time of surgery was likely > 38. Correct, it was actually a couple of months before the surgery, so I don't really know what it was at surgery but I'm sure it didn't go down. The 1/2 Life of circulating PSA is approx 2-3 days so by 30 days, it should be approaching it's lowest level First time anyone's told me this. Thanks. Did you have a standard or ultrasensitive PSA (uPSA) test? If uPSA, (the result will be out to 3 decimal points), be sure to go to The Same Lab and get The Exact Same PSA test next time. Only then can you compare your first 2 post op PSA values It's the same lab but I don't know if it's ultra sensitive or not. I'll ask. Your final path report downgraded you from G8 to G7. Congrats! This still places you in an intermediate risk category. Yes, that was good to hear and my Urologist/Surgeon said that based on the pathology report follow on treatment in the form of Radiation/Chemo was not indicated, at least not at this time. I'm sure hoping for a PSA of zero but the 4 week interval had me worried.

Posts.Content: Thanks to all who replied. Nick
Posts.Title: Follow up Blood Test Too Soon?

Posts.Content: I started Lupron right after completing radiation treatment. It kicked my Butt. So which was it? The radiation or the Lupron? The Lupron shots are virtually painless. Once I didn't even know I got the shot until they said they were done.
Posts.Title: One year on Lupron

Posts.Content: I've had my 4th Lupron injection, 4 more to go over the next year, then we see where to go from there. PSA <0.1 or essentially unmeasurable. What I've noticed is an almost complete loss of body hair (except whiskers), loss of muscle tone, zero libido, general loss of energy, but all in all, not too bad. My legs tire quickly but I'm trying to extend my endurance with daily walks. How have others fared? Am I typical? Nick P.
Posts.Title: One year on Lupron

Posts.Content: Prostate removal in mid-October with a PSA of 37. 4 week PSA was 0.6. 3 months later it was 0.8. It is now 1.0. Obviously I'm in line for hormonal therapy but my oncologist says radiation treatment still offers me a 1 out of 8 chance of a cure. Who has gone through that and what are the chances of side effects? Are they a certainty? If I forego radiation, when does hormonal treatment start? I don't have another appointment with my oncologist until August. Nick

Posts.Title: 7 Month update

Posts.Content: MichiganMan Why am I waiting? I'm following the advice I'm given. My Surgeon is the Professor of Urology and my Oncologist is the Professor of Medicine and Surgery, both at the University of Arizona Cancer Center. I figured I was in good hands. I've put in a call to see if I can accelerate this treatment schedule after the comments I've received here. Nick
Posts.Title: 7 Month update

Posts.Content: Michael My care is being handled by the Banner Cancer Center of the University of Arizona, Tucson. My Oncologist is the Professor of Medicine and Surgery there who specializes in only prostate cancer and testicular cancer, so I feel I am in good hands. He is scheduling a consultation with the RO. It has not been scheduled yet. I do not have the complete lab results but I know my Gleason score was 7. There was Seminal Vesicle Involvement but nothing more. I am 68 and otherwise in good health. Thanks for responding.
Posts.Title: 7 Month update

Posts.Content: RobLee You sound just like me. So how is your shoe collection coming along?
Posts.Title: One year on Lupron

Posts.Content: rooster I was also under the impression that Lupron only puts cancer cells into hibernation but my Doctor explained slightly differently. She said it starves them and hopefully kills them by starvation. Essentially the same thing you said but worded a little differently.

Posts.Title: 7 Month update

Posts.Content: I'm 7 weeks post op and my 4 week PSA was 0.6 (not 0.5 as I reported in a earlier thread), down from 38 per-surgery. My surgeon said a 4 week PSA was too soon to draw any conclusions so we'll wait for my 3 month test. With my gleason score of 7 he said I had a 30% chance of needing followup radiation or hormonal treatment. I found it odd that he would mention hormonal treatment at this stage, but what do I know? My continence has improved considerably in the last week to 10 days. Have patience toloh, you're making progress, that's what's important and it will continue. Nick
Posts.Title: PSA Six weeks after surgery.
